@timestamp.description:
Date/time when the event originated.
This is the date/time extracted from the event, typically representing when the event was generated by the source.
If the event source has no original timestamp, this value is typically populated by the first time the event was received by the pipeline.
Required field for all events.
@timestamp.name: @timestamp

agent.ephemeral_id.description:
Ephemeral identifier of this agent (if one exists).
This id normally changes across restarts, but `agent.id` does not.
agent.ephemeral_id.name: ephemeral_id

agent.id.description:
Unique identifier of this agent (if one exists).
Example: For Beats this would be beat.id.
agent.id.name: id

agent.name.description:
Custom name of the agent.
This is a name that can be given to an agent. This can be helpful if for example two Filebeat instances are running on the same host but a human readable separation is needed on which Filebeat instance data is coming from.
If no name is given, the name is often left empty.
agent.name.name: name

agent.type.description:
Type of the agent.
The agent type stays always the same and should be given by the agent used. In case of Filebeat the agent would always be Filebeat also if two Filebeat instances are run on the same machine.
agent.type.name: type

as.number.description: Unique number allocated to the autonomous system. The autonomous system number (ASN) uniquely identifies each network on the Internet.
as.number.name: number
as.number.short: Unique number allocated to the autonomous system. The autonomous system number (ASN) uniquely identifies each network on the Internet.

client.address.description:
Some event client addresses are defined ambiguously. The event will sometimes list an IP, a domain or a unix socket.  You should always store the raw address in the `.address` field.
Then it should be duplicated to `.ip` or `.domain`, depending on which one it is.
client.address.name: address

client.as.number.description: Unique number allocated to the autonomous system. The autonomous system number (ASN) uniquely identifies each network on the Internet.
client.as.number.name: number
client.as.number.short: Unique number allocated to the autonomous system. The autonomous system number (ASN) uniquely identifies each network on the Internet.

client.bytes.description: Bytes sent from the client to the server.
client.bytes.name: bytes
client.bytes.short: Bytes sent from the client to the server.

client.geo.name.description:
User-defined description of a location, at the level of granularity they care about.
Could be the name of their data centers, the floor number, if this describes a local physical entity, city names.
Not typically used in automated geolocation.
client.geo.name.name: name

client.ip.description:
IP address of the client.
Can be one or multiple IPv4 or IPv6 addresses.
client.ip.name: ip

client.nat.ip.description:
Translated IP of source based NAT sessions (e.g. internal client to internet).
Typically connections traversing load balancers, firewalls, or routers.
client.nat.ip.name: nat.ip

client.nat.port.description:
Translated port of source based NAT sessions (e.g. internal client to internet).
Typically connections traversing load balancers, firewalls, or routers.
client.nat.port.name: nat.port

client.packets.description: Packets sent from the client to the server.
client.packets.name: packets
client.packets.short: Packets sent from the client to the server.

client.registered_domain.description:
The highest registered client domain, stripped of the subdomain.
For example, the registered domain for "foo.google.com" is "google.com".
This value can be determined precisely with a list like the public suffix list (http://publicsuffix.org). Trying to approximate this by simply taking the last two labels will not work well for TLDs such as "co.uk".
client.registered_domain.name: registered_domain
client.registered_domain.short: The highest registered client domain, stripped of the subdomain.

client.top_level_domain.description:
The effective top level domain (eTLD), also known as the domain suffix, is the last part of the domain name. For example, the top level domain for google.com is "com".
This value can be determined precisely with a list like the public suffix list (http://publicsuffix.org). Trying to approximate this by simply taking the last label will not work well for effective TLDs such as "co.uk".
client.top_level_domain.name: top_level_domain
client.top_level_domain.short: The effective top level domain (com, org, net, co.uk).

client.user.domain.description:
Name of the directory the user is a member of.
For example, an LDAP or Active Directory domain name.
client.user.domain.name: domain
client.user.domain.short: Name of the directory the user is a member of.

client.user.group.domain.description:
Name of the directory the group is a member of.
For example, an LDAP or Active Directory domain name.
client.user.group.domain.name: domain
client.user.group.domain.short: Name of the directory the group is a member of.

client.user.group.id.description: Unique identifier for the group on the system/platform.
client.user.group.id.name: id
client.user.group.id.short: Unique identifier for the group on the system/platform.

client.user.hash.description:
Unique user hash to correlate information for a user in anonymized form.
Useful if `user.id` or `user.name` contain confidential information and cannot be used.
client.user.hash.name: hash
client.user.hash.short: Unique user hash to correlate information for a user in anonymized form.

client.user.id.description: One or multiple unique identifiers of the user.
client.user.id.name: id
client.user.id.short: One or multiple unique identifiers of the user.

client.user.name.description: Short name or login of the user.
client.user.name.name: name
client.user.name.short: Short name or login of the user.

cloud.account.id.description:
The cloud account or organization id used to identify different entities in a multi-tenant environment.
Examples: AWS account id, Google Cloud ORG Id, or other unique identifier.
cloud.account.id.name: account.id
cloud.account.id.short: The cloud account or organization id.

cloud.availability_zone.description: Availability zone in which this host is running.
cloud.availability_zone.name: availability_zone
cloud.availability_zone.short: Availability zone in which this host is running.

cloud.instance.id.description: Instance ID of the host machine.
cloud.instance.id.name: instance.id
cloud.instance.id.short: Instance ID of the host machine.

cloud.instance.name.description: Instance name of the host machine.
cloud.instance.name.name: instance.name
cloud.instance.name.short: Instance name of the host machine.

cloud.machine.type.description: Machine type of the host machine.
cloud.machine.type.name: machine.type
cloud.machine.type.short: Machine type of the host machine.

cloud.provider.description: Name of the cloud provider. Example values are aws, azure, gcp, or digitalocean.
cloud.provider.name: provider

cloud.region.description: Region in which this host is running.
cloud.region.name: region
cloud.region.short: Region in which this host is running.

container.image.name.description: Name of the image the container was built on.
container.image.name.name: image.name
container.image.name.short: Name of the image the container was built on.

destination.address.description:
Some event destination addresses are defined ambiguously. The event will sometimes list an IP, a domain or a unix socket.  You should always store the raw address in the `.address` field.
Then it should be duplicated to `.ip` or `.domain`, depending on which one it is.
destination.address.name: address

destination.as.number.description: Unique number allocated to the autonomous system. The autonomous system number (ASN) uniquely identifies each network on the Internet.
destination.as.number.name: number
destination.as.number.short: Unique number allocated to the autonomous system. The autonomous system number (ASN) uniquely identifies each network on the Internet.

destination.bytes.description: Bytes sent from the destination to the source.
destination.bytes.name: bytes
destination.bytes.short: Bytes sent from the destination to the source.

destination.geo.name.description:
User-defined description of a location, at the level of granularity they care about.
Could be the name of their data centers, the floor number, if this describes a local physical entity, city names.
Not typically used in automated geolocation.
destination.geo.name.name: name

destination.ip.description:
IP address of the destination.
Can be one or multiple IPv4 or IPv6 addresses.
destination.ip.name: ip

destination.nat.ip.description:
Translated ip of destination based NAT sessions (e.g. internet to private DMZ)
Typically used with load balancers, firewalls, or routers.
destination.nat.ip.name: nat.ip

destination.nat.port.description:
Port the source session is translated to by NAT Device.
Typically used with load balancers, firewalls, or routers.
destination.nat.port.name: nat.port

destination.packets.description: Packets sent from the destination to the source.
destination.packets.name: packets
destination.packets.short: Packets sent from the destination to the source.

destination.registered_domain.description:
The highest registered destination domain, stripped of the subdomain.
For example, the registered domain for "foo.google.com" is "google.com".
This value can be determined precisely with a list like the public suffix list (http://publicsuffix.org). Trying to approximate this by simply taking the last two labels will not work well for TLDs such as "co.uk".
destination.registered_domain.name: registered_domain
destination.registered_domain.short: The highest registered destination domain, stripped of the subdomain.

destination.top_level_domain.description:
The effective top level domain (eTLD), also known as the domain suffix, is the last part of the domain name. For example, the top level domain for google.com is "com".
This value can be determined precisely with a list like the public suffix list (http://publicsuffix.org). Trying to approximate this by simply taking the last label will not work well for effective TLDs such as "co.uk".
destination.top_level_domain.name: top_level_domain
destination.top_level_domain.short: The effective top level domain (com, org, net, co.uk).

destination.user.domain.description:
Name of the directory the user is a member of.
For example, an LDAP or Active Directory domain name.
destination.user.domain.name: domain
destination.user.domain.short: Name of the directory the user is a member of.

destination.user.group.domain.description:
Name of the directory the group is a member of.
For example, an LDAP or Active Directory domain name.
destination.user.group.domain.name: domain
destination.user.group.domain.short: Name of the directory the group is a member of.

destination.user.group.id.description: Unique identifier for the group on the system/platform.
destination.user.group.id.name: id
destination.user.group.id.short: Unique identifier for the group on the system/platform.

destination.user.hash.description:
Unique user hash to correlate information for a user in anonymized form.
Useful if `user.id` or `user.name` contain confidential information and cannot be used.
destination.user.hash.name: hash
destination.user.hash.short: Unique user hash to correlate information for a user in anonymized form.

destination.user.id.description: One or multiple unique identifiers of the user.
destination.user.id.name: id
destination.user.id.short: One or multiple unique identifiers of the user.

destination.user.name.description: Short name or login of the user.
destination.user.name.name: name
destination.user.name.short: Short name or login of the user.

dns.answers.description:
An array containing an object for each answer section returned by the server.
The main keys that should be present in these objects are defined by ECS. Records that have more information may contain more keys than what ECS defines.
Not all DNS data sources give all details about DNS answers. At minimum, answer objects must contain the `data` key. If more information is available, map as much of it to ECS as possible, and add any additional fields to the answer objects as custom fields.
dns.answers.name: answers

dns.answers.class.description: The class of DNS data contained in this resource record.
dns.answers.class.name: answers.class
dns.answers.class.short: The class of DNS data contained in this resource record.

dns.answers.data.description:
The data describing the resource.
The meaning of this data depends on the type and class of the resource record.
dns.answers.data.name: answers.data

dns.answers.name.description:
The domain name to which this resource record pertains.
If a chain of CNAME is being resolved, each answer's `name` should be the one that corresponds with the answer's `data`. It should not simply be the original `question.name` repeated.
dns.answers.name.name: answers.name
dns.answers.name.short: The domain name to which this resource record pertains.

dns.answers.ttl.description: The time interval in seconds that this resource record may be cached before it should be discarded. Zero values mean that the data should not be cached.
dns.answers.ttl.name: answers.ttl
dns.answers.ttl.short: The time interval in seconds that this resource record may be cached before it should be discarded. Zero values mean that the data should not be cached.

dns.answers.type.description: The type of data contained in this resource record.
dns.answers.type.name: answers.type
dns.answers.type.short: The type of data contained in this resource record.

dns.header_flags.description:
Array of 2 letter DNS header flags.
Expected values are: AA, TC, RD, RA, AD, CD, DO.
dns.header_flags.name: header_flags

dns.id.description: The DNS packet identifier assigned by the program that generated the query. The identifier is copied to the response.
dns.id.name: id
dns.id.short: The DNS packet identifier assigned by the program that generated the query. The identifier is copied to the response.

dns.op_code.description: The DNS operation code that specifies the kind of query in the message. This value is set by the originator of a query and copied into the response.
dns.op_code.name: op_code
dns.op_code.short: The DNS operation code that specifies the kind of query in the message. This value is set by the originator of a query and copied into the response.

dns.question.class.description: The class of of records being queried.
dns.question.class.name: question.class
dns.question.class.short: The class of of records being queried.

dns.question.name.description:
The name being queried.
If the name field contains non-printable characters (below 32 or above 126), those characters should be represented as escaped base 10 integers (\DDD). Back slashes and quotes should be escaped. Tabs, carriage returns, and line feeds should be converted to \t, \r, and \n respectively.
dns.question.name.name: question.name

dns.question.registered_domain.description:
The highest registered domain, stripped of the subdomain.
For example, the registered domain for "foo.google.com" is "google.com".
This value can be determined precisely with a list like the public suffix list (http://publicsuffix.org). Trying to approximate this by simply taking the last two labels will not work well for TLDs such as "co.uk".
dns.question.registered_domain.name: question.registered_domain
dns.question.registered_domain.short: The highest registered domain, stripped of the subdomain.

dns.question.subdomain.description:
The subdomain is all of the labels under the registered_domain.
If the domain has multiple levels of subdomain, such as "sub2.sub1.example.com", the subdomain field should contain "sub2.sub1", with no trailing period.
dns.question.subdomain.name: question.subdomain

dns.question.top_level_domain.description:
The effective top level domain (eTLD), also known as the domain suffix, is the last part of the domain name. For example, the top level domain for google.com is "com".
This value can be determined precisely with a list like the public suffix list (http://publicsuffix.org). Trying to approximate this by simply taking the last label will not work well for effective TLDs such as "co.uk".
dns.question.top_level_domain.name: question.top_level_domain
dns.question.top_level_domain.short: The effective top level domain (com, org, net, co.uk).

dns.question.type.description: The type of record being queried.
dns.question.type.name: question.type
dns.question.type.short: The type of record being queried.

dns.resolved_ip.description:
Array containing all IPs seen in `answers.data`.
The `answers` array can be difficult to use, because of the variety of data formats it can contain. Extracting all IP addresses seen in there to `dns.resolved_ip` makes it possible to index them as IP addresses, and makes them easier to visualize and query for.
dns.resolved_ip.name: resolved_ip
dns.resolved_ip.short: Array containing all IPs seen in answers.data

dns.type.description:
The type of DNS event captured, query or answer.
If your source of DNS events only gives you DNS queries, you should only create dns events of type `dns.type:query`.
If your source of DNS events gives you answers as well, you should create one event per query (optionally as soon as the query is seen). And a second event containing all query details as well as an array of answers.
dns.type.name: type
dns.type.short: The type of DNS event captured, query or answer.

ecs.version.description:
ECS version this event conforms to. `ecs.version` is a required field and must exist in all events.
When querying across multiple indices -- which may conform to slightly different ECS versions -- this field lets integrations adjust to the schema version of the events.
ecs.version.name: version
ecs.version.short: ECS version this event conforms to.

error.stack_trace.description: The stack trace of this error in plain text.
error.stack_trace.name: stack_trace
error.stack_trace.short: The stack trace of this error in plain text.

error.type.description: The type of the error, for example the class name of the exception.
error.type.name: type
error.type.short: The type of the error, for example the class name of the exception.

event.action.description:
The action captured by the event.
This describes the information in the event. It is more specific than `event.category`. Examples are `group-add`, `process-started`, `file-created`. The value is normally defined by the implementer.
event.action.name: action
event.action.short: The action captured by the event.

event.category.description:
Event category.
This contains high-level information about the contents of the event. It is more generic than `event.action`, in the sense that typically a category contains multiple actions. Warning: In future versions of ECS, we plan to provide a list of acceptable values for this field, please use with caution.
event.category.name: category

event.code.description:
Identification code for this event, if one exists.
Some event sources use event codes to identify messages unambiguously, regardless of message language or wording adjustments over time. An example of this is the Windows Event ID.
event.code.name: code

event.created.description:
event.created contains the date/time when the event was first read by an agent, or by your pipeline.
This field is distinct from @timestamp in that @timestamp typically contain the time extracted from the original event.
In most situations, these two timestamps will be slightly different. The difference can be used to calculate the delay between your source generating an event, and the time when your agent first processed it. This can be used to monitor your agent's or pipeline's ability to keep up with your event source.
In case the two timestamps are identical, @timestamp should be used.
event.created.name: created
event.created.short: Time when the event was first read by an agent or by your pipeline.

event.dataset.description:
Name of the dataset.
If an event source publishes more than one type of log or events (e.g. access log, error log), the dataset is used to specify which one the event comes from.
It's recommended but not required to start the dataset name with the module name, followed by a dot, then the dataset name.
event.dataset.name: dataset

event.duration.description:
Duration of the event in nanoseconds.
If event.start and event.end are known this value should be the difference between the end and start time.
event.duration.name: duration
event.duration.short: Duration of the event in nanoseconds.

event.end.description: event.end contains the date when the event ended or when the activity was last observed.
event.end.name: end
event.end.short: event.end contains the date when the event ended or when the activity was last observed.

event.hash.description: Hash (perhaps logstash fingerprint) of raw field to be able to demonstrate log integrity.
event.hash.name: hash
event.hash.short: Hash (perhaps logstash fingerprint) of raw field to be able to demonstrate log integrity.

event.id.description: Unique ID to describe the event.
event.id.name: id
event.id.short: Unique ID to describe the event.

event.ingested.description:
Timestamp when an event arrived in the central data store.
This is different from `@timestamp`, which is when the event originally occurred.  It's also different from `event.created`, which is meant to capture the first time an agent saw the event.
In normal conditions, assuming no tampering, the timestamps should chronologically look like this: `@timestamp` < `event.created` < `event.ingested`.
event.ingested.name: ingested
event.ingested.short: Timestamp when an event arrived in the central data store.

event.kind.description:
The kind of the event.
This gives information about what type of information the event contains, without being specific to the contents of the event.  Examples are `event`, `state`, `alarm`. Warning: In future versions of ECS, we plan to provide a list of acceptable values for this field, please use with caution.
event.kind.name: kind

event.module.description:
Name of the module this data is coming from.
If your monitoring agent supports the concept of modules or plugins to process events of a given source (e.g. Apache logs), `event.module` should contain the name of this module.
event.module.name: module
event.module.short: Name of the module this data is coming from.

event.original.description:
Raw text message of entire event. Used to demonstrate log integrity.
This field is not indexed and doc_values are disabled. It cannot be searched, but it can be retrieved from `_source`.
event.original.example: Sep 19 08:26:10 host CEF:0|Security| threatmanager|1.0|100| worm successfully stopped|10|src=10.0.0.1 dst=2.1.2.2spt=1232
event.original.name: original
event.original.short: Raw text message of entire event.

event.outcome.description:
The outcome of the event.
If the event describes an action, this fields contains the outcome of that action. Examples outcomes are `success` and `failure`. Warning: In future versions of ECS, we plan to provide a list of acceptable values for this field, please use with caution.
event.outcome.name: outcome

event.provider.description:
Source of the event.
Event transports such as Syslog or the Windows Event Log typically mention the source of an event. It can be the name of the software that generated the event (e.g. Sysmon, httpd), or of a subsystem of the operating system (kernel, Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing).
event.provider.name: provider

event.risk_score.description: Risk score or priority of the event (e.g. security solutions). Use your system's original value here.
event.risk_score.name: risk_score
event.risk_score.short: Risk score or priority of the event (e.g. security solutions). Use your system's original value here.

event.risk_score_norm.description:
Normalized risk score or priority of the event, on a scale of 0 to 100.
This is mainly useful if you use more than one system that assigns risk scores, and you want to see a normalized value across all systems.
event.risk_score_norm.name: risk_score_norm
event.risk_score_norm.short: Normalized risk score or priority of the event (0-100).

event.sequence.description:
Sequence number of the event.
The sequence number is a value published by some event sources, to make the exact ordering of events unambiguous, regarless of the timestamp precision.
event.sequence.name: sequence

event.severity.description:
The numeric severity of the event according to your event source.
What the different severity values mean can be different between sources and use cases. It's up to the implementer to make sure severities are consistent across events from the same source.
The Syslog severity belongs in `log.syslog.severity.code`. `event.severity` is meant to represent the severity according to the event source (e.g. firewall, IDS). If the event source does not publish its own severity, you may optionally copy the `log.syslog.severity.code` to `event.severity`.
event.severity.name: severity

event.start.description: event.start contains the date when the event started or when the activity was first observed.
event.start.name: start
event.start.short: event.start contains the date when the event started or when the activity was first observed.

event.timezone.description:
This field should be populated when the event's timestamp does not include timezone information already (e.g. default Syslog timestamps). It's optional otherwise.
Acceptable timezone formats are: a canonical ID (e.g. "Europe/Amsterdam"), abbreviated (e.g. "EST") or an HH:mm differential (e.g. "-05:00").
event.timezone.name: timezone

event.type.description:
Reserved for future usage.
Please avoid using this field for user data.
event.type.name: type

file.accessed.description:
Last time the file was accessed.
Note that not all filesystems keep track of access time.
file.accessed.name: accessed
file.accessed.short: Last time the file was accessed.

file.created.description:
File creation time.
Note that not all filesystems store the creation time.
file.created.name: created

file.ctime.description:
Last time the file attributes or metadata changed.
Note that changes to the file content will update `mtime`. This implies `ctime` will be adjusted at the same time, since `mtime` is an attribute of the file.
file.ctime.name: ctime
file.ctime.short: Last time the file attributes or metadata changed.

file.device.description: Device that is the source of the file.
file.device.name: device
file.device.short: Device that is the source of the file.

file.directory.description: Directory where the file is located.
file.directory.name: directory
file.directory.short: Directory where the file is located.

file.gid.description: Primary group ID (GID) of the file.
file.gid.name: gid
file.gid.short: Primary group ID (GID) of the file.

file.group.description: Primary group name of the file.
file.group.name: group
file.group.short: Primary group name of the file.

file.inode.description: Inode representing the file in the filesystem.
file.inode.name: inode
file.inode.short: Inode representing the file in the filesystem.

file.mode.description: Mode of the file in octal representation.
file.mode.name: mode
file.mode.short: Mode of the file in octal representation.

file.mtime.description: Last time the file content was modified.
file.mtime.name: mtime
file.mtime.short: Last time the file content was modified.

file.name.description: Name of the file including the extension, without the directory.
file.name.name: name
file.name.short: Name of the file including the extension, without the directory.

file.size.description:
File size in bytes.
Only relevant when `file.type` is "file".
file.size.name: size

file.uid.description: The user ID (UID) or security identifier (SID) of the file owner.
file.uid.name: uid
file.uid.short: The user ID (UID) or security identifier (SID) of the file owner.

geo.name.description:
User-defined description of a location, at the level of granularity they care about.
Could be the name of their data centers, the floor number, if this describes a local physical entity, city names.
Not typically used in automated geolocation.
geo.name.name: name

group.domain.description:
Name of the directory the group is a member of.
For example, an LDAP or Active Directory domain name.
group.domain.name: domain
group.domain.short: Name of the directory the group is a member of.

group.id.description: Unique identifier for the group on the system/platform.
group.id.name: id
group.id.short: Unique identifier for the group on the system/platform.

host.domain.description:
Name of the domain of which the host is a member. 
For example, on Windows this could be the host's Active Directory domain or NetBIOS domain name.  For Linux this could be the domain of the host's LDAP provider.
host.domain.name: domain
host.domain.short: Name of the directory the group is a member of.

host.geo.name.description:
User-defined description of a location, at the level of granularity they care about.
Could be the name of their data centers, the floor number, if this describes a local physical entity, city names.
Not typically used in automated geolocation.
host.geo.name.name: name

host.hostname.description:
Hostname of the host.
It normally contains what the `hostname` command returns on the host machine.
host.hostname.name: hostname

host.id.description:
Unique host id.
As hostname is not always unique, use values that are meaningful in your environment.
Example: The current usage of `beat.name`.
host.id.name: id

host.name.description:
Name of the host.
It can contain what `hostname` returns on Unix systems, the fully qualified domain name, or a name specified by the user. The sender decides which value to use.
host.name.name: name

host.os.family.description: OS family (such as redhat, debian, freebsd, windows).
host.os.family.name: family
host.os.family.short: OS family (such as redhat, debian, freebsd, windows).

host.os.full.description: Operating system name, including the version or code name.
host.os.full.name: full
host.os.full.short: Operating system name, including the version or code name.

host.os.kernel.description: Operating system kernel version as a raw string.
host.os.kernel.name: kernel
host.os.kernel.short: Operating system kernel version as a raw string.

host.os.name.description: Operating system name, without the version.

host.os.platform.description: Operating system platform (such centos, ubuntu, windows).

host.os.version.description: Operating system version as a raw string.

host.os.version.short: Operating system version as a raw string.

host.type.description:
Type of host.
For Cloud providers this can be the machine type like `t2.medium`. If vm, this could be the container, for example, or other information meaningful in your environment.
host.type.name: type

host.uptime.description: Seconds the host has been up.
host.uptime.name: uptime
host.uptime.short: Seconds the host has been up.

host.user.domain.description:
Name of the directory the user is a member of.
For example, an LDAP or Active Directory domain name.
host.user.domain.name: domain
host.user.domain.short: Name of the directory the user is a member of.

host.user.group.domain.description:
Name of the directory the group is a member of.
For example, an LDAP or Active Directory domain name.
host.user.group.domain.name: domain
host.user.group.domain.short: Name of the directory the group is a member of.

host.user.group.id.description: Unique identifier for the group on the system/platform.
host.user.group.id.name: id
host.user.group.id.short: Unique identifier for the group on the system/platform.

host.user.hash.description:
Unique user hash to correlate information for a user in anonymized form.
Useful if `user.id` or `user.name` contain confidential information and cannot be used.
host.user.hash.name: hash
host.user.hash.short: Unique user hash to correlate information for a user in anonymized form.

host.user.id.description: One or multiple unique identifiers of the user.
host.user.id.name: id
host.user.id.short: One or multiple unique identifiers of the user.

host.user.name.description: Short name or login of the user.
host.user.name.name: name
host.user.name.short: Short name or login of the user.

http.request.body.bytes.name: request.body.bytes
http.request.body.bytes.short: Size in bytes of the request body.

http.request.bytes.name: request.bytes
http.request.bytes.short: Total size in bytes of the request (body and headers).

http.request.method.description:
HTTP request method.
The field value must be normalized to lowercase for querying. See the documentation section "Implementing ECS".
http.request.method.name: request.method

http.response.body.bytes.description: Size in bytes of the response body.
http.response.body.bytes.name: response.body.bytes
http.response.body.bytes.short: Size in bytes of the response body.

labels.description:
Custom key/value pairs.
Can be used to add meta information to events. Should not contain nested objects. All values are stored as keyword.
Example: `docker` and `k8s` labels.
labels.name: labels

log.level.description:
Original log level of the log event.
If the source of the event provides a log level or textual severity, this is the one that goes in `log.level`. If your source doesn't specify one, you may put your event transport's severity here (e.g. Syslog severity).
Some examples are `warn`, `err`, `i`, `informational`.
log.level.name: level
log.level.short: Log level of the log event.

log.logger.description: The name of the logger inside an application. This is usually the name of the class which initialized the logger, or can be a custom name.
log.logger.name: logger

log.origin.file.line.description: The line number of the file containing the source code which originated the log event.
log.origin.file.line.name: origin.file.line
log.origin.file.line.short: The line number of the file which originated the log event.

log.origin.file.name.description: The name of the file containing the source code which originated the log event. Note that this is not the name of the log file.
log.origin.file.name.name: origin.file.name
log.origin.file.name.short: The file which originated the log event.

log.origin.function.description: The name of the function or method which originated the log event.
log.origin.function.name: origin.function
log.origin.function.short: The function which originated the log event.

log.original.description:
This is the original log message and contains the full log message before splitting it up in multiple parts.
In contrast to the `message` field which can contain an extracted part of the log message, this field contains the original, full log message. It can have already some modifications applied like encoding or new lines removed to clean up the log message.
This field is not indexed and doc_values are disabled so it can't be queried but the value can be retrieved from `_source`.
log.original.name: original
log.original.short: Original log message with light interpretation only (encoding, newlines).

log.syslog.description: The Syslog metadata of the event, if the event was transmitted via Syslog. Please see RFCs 5424 or 3164.
log.syslog.name: syslog

log.syslog.facility.code.description:
The Syslog numeric facility of the log event, if available.
According to RFCs 5424 and 3164, this value should be an integer between 0 and 23.
log.syslog.facility.code.name: syslog.facility.code
log.syslog.facility.code.short: Syslog numeric facility of the event.

log.syslog.facility.name.description: The Syslog text-based facility of the log event, if available.
log.syslog.facility.name.name: syslog.facility.name
log.syslog.facility.name.short: Syslog text-based facility of the event.

log.syslog.priority.description:
Syslog numeric priority of the event, if available.
According to RFCs 5424 and 3164, the priority is 8 * facility + severity. This number is therefore expected to contain a value between 0 and 191.
log.syslog.priority.name: syslog.priority

log.syslog.severity.code.description:
The Syslog numeric severity of the log event, if available.
If the event source publishing via Syslog provides a different numeric severity value (e.g. firewall, IDS), your source's numeric severity should go to `event.severity`. If the event source does not specify a distinct severity, you can optionally copy the Syslog severity to `event.severity`.
log.syslog.severity.code.name: syslog.severity.code
log.syslog.severity.code.short: Syslog numeric severity of the event.

log.syslog.severity.name.description:
The Syslog numeric severity of the log event, if available.
If the event source publishing via Syslog provides a different severity value (e.g. firewall, IDS), your source's text severity should go to `log.level`. If the event source does not specify a distinct severity, you can optionally copy the Syslog severity to `log.level`.
log.syslog.severity.name.name: syslog.severity.name
log.syslog.severity.name.short: Syslog text-based severity of the event.

message.description:
For log events the message field contains the log message, optimized for viewing in a log viewer.
For structured logs without an original message field, other fields can be concatenated to form a human-readable summary of the event.
If multiple messages exist, they can be combined into one message.
message.name: message
message.short: Log message optimized for viewing in a log viewer.

network.application.description:
A name given to an application level protocol. This can be arbitrarily assigned for things like microservices, but also apply to things like skype, icq, facebook, twitter. This would be used in situations where the vendor or service can be decoded such as from the source/dest IP owners, ports, or wire format.
The field value must be normalized to lowercase for querying. See the documentation section "Implementing ECS".
network.application.name: application

network.bytes.description:
Total bytes transferred in both directions.
If `source.bytes` and `destination.bytes` are known, `network.bytes` is their sum.
network.bytes.name: bytes
network.bytes.short: Total bytes transferred in both directions.

network.community_id.description:
A hash of source and destination IPs and ports, as well as the protocol used in a communication. This is a tool-agnostic standard to identify flows.
Learn more at https://github.com/corelight/community-id-spec.
network.community_id.name: community_id
network.community_id.short: A hash of source and destination IPs and ports.

network.direction.description:
Direction of the network traffic.
Recommended values are:
  * inbound
  * outbound
  * internal
  * external
  * unknown

When mapping events from a host-based monitoring context, populate this field from the host's point of view.
When mapping events from a network or perimeter-based monitoring context, populate this field from the point of view of your network perimeter.
network.direction.name: direction

network.forwarded_ip.description: Host IP address when the source IP address is the proxy.
network.forwarded_ip.name: forwarded_ip
network.forwarded_ip.short: Host IP address when the source IP address is the proxy.

network.iana_number.description: IANA Protocol Number (https://www.iana.org/assignments/protocol-numbers/protocol-numbers.xhtml). Standardized list of protocols. This aligns well with NetFlow and sFlow related logs which use the IANA Protocol Number.
network.iana_number.name: iana_number

network.name.description: Name given by operators to sections of their network.
network.name.name: name
network.name.short: Name given by operators to sections of their network.

network.packets.description:
Total packets transferred in both directions.
If `source.packets` and `destination.packets` are known, `network.packets` is their sum.
network.packets.name: packets
network.packets.short: Total packets transferred in both directions.

network.protocol.description:
L7 Network protocol name. ex. http, lumberjack, transport protocol.
The field value must be normalized to lowercase for querying. See the documentation section "Implementing ECS".
network.protocol.name: protocol

network.transport.description:
Same as network.iana_number, but instead using the Keyword name of the transport layer (udp, tcp, ipv6-icmp, etc.)
The field value must be normalized to lowercase for querying. See the documentation section "Implementing ECS".
network.transport.name: transport
network.transport.short: Protocol Name corresponding to the field `iana_number`.

network.type.description:
In the OSI Model this would be the Network Layer. ipv4, ipv6, ipsec, pim, etc
The field value must be normalized to lowercase for querying. See the documentation section "Implementing ECS".
network.type.name: type
network.type.short: In the OSI Model this would be the Network Layer. ipv4, ipv6, ipsec, pim, etc

observer.geo.name.description:
User-defined description of a location, at the level of granularity they care about.
Could be the name of their data centers, the floor number, if this describes a local physical entity, city names.
Not typically used in automated geolocation.
observer.geo.name.name: name

observer.name.description:
Custom name of the observer.
This is a name that can be given to an observer. This can be helpful for example if multiple firewalls of the same model are used in an organization.
If no custom name is needed, the field can be left empty.
observer.name.name: name

observer.os.family.description: OS family (such as redhat, debian, freebsd, windows).
observer.os.family.name: family
observer.os.family.short: OS family (such as redhat, debian, freebsd, windows).

observer.os.full.description: Operating system name, including the version or code name.
observer.os.full.name: full
observer.os.full.short: Operating system name, including the version or code name.

observer.os.kernel.name: kernel

observer.os.name.description: Operating system name, without the version.
observer.os.name.name: name
observer.os.name.short: Operating system name, without the version.

observer.os.platform.description: Operating system platform (such centos, ubuntu, windows).
observer.os.platform.name: platform
observer.os.platform.short: Operating system platform (such centos, ubuntu, windows).

observer.os.version.description: Operating system version as a raw string.
observer.os.version.name: version
observer.os.version.short: Operating system version as a raw string.

observer.product.description: The product name of the observer.
observer.product.name: product
observer.product.short: The product name of the observer.

observer.type.description:
The type of the observer the data is coming from.
There is no predefined list of observer types. Some examples are `forwarder`, `firewall`, `ids`, `ips`, `proxy`, `poller`, `sensor`, `APM server`.
observer.type.name: type
observer.type.short: The type of the observer the data is coming from.

os.family.description: OS family (such as redhat, debian, freebsd, windows).
os.family.name: family
os.family.short: OS family (such as redhat, debian, freebsd, windows).

os.full.description: Operating system name, including the version or code name.
os.full.name: full
os.full.short: Operating system name, including the version or code name.

os.kernel.description: Operating system kernel version as a raw string.
os.kernel.name: kernel

os.name.name: name

os.platform.description: Operating system platform (such centos, ubuntu, windows).
os.platform.name: platform
os.platform.short: Operating system platform (such centos, ubuntu, windows).

os.version.description: Operating system version as a raw string.
os.version.name: version
os.version.short: Operating system version as a raw string.

package.build_version.description:
Additional information about the build version of the installed package.
For example use the commit SHA of a non-released package.
package.build_version.name: build_version

package.checksum.description: Checksum of the installed package for verification.
package.checksum.name: checksum
package.checksum.short: Checksum of the installed package for verification.

package.description.example: Open source programming language to build simple/reliable/efficient software.
package.description.name: description

package.install_scope.description: Indicating how the package was installed, e.g. user-local, global.
package.install_scope.name: install_scope
package.install_scope.short: Indicating how the package was installed, e.g. user-local, global.

package.license.description:
License under which the package was released.
Use a short name, e.g. the license identifier from SPDX License List where possible (https://spdx.org/licenses/).
package.license.name: license

package.path.description: Path where the package is installed.
package.path.name: path
package.path.short: Path where the package is installed.

package.reference.description: Home page or reference URL of the software in this package, if available.
package.reference.name: reference
package.reference.short: Package home page or reference URL

package.type.description:
Type of package.
This should contain the package file type, rather than the package manager name. Examples: rpm, dpkg, brew, npm, gem, nupkg, jar.
package.type.name: type

process.args.description:
Array of process arguments, starting with the absolute path to the executable.
May be filtered to protect sensitive information.
process.args.name: args

process.args_count.description:
Length of the process.args array.
This field can be useful for querying or performing bucket analysis on how many arguments were provided to start a process. More arguments may be an indication of suspicious activity.
process.args_count.name: args_count

process.command_line.description:
Full command line that started the process, including the absolute path to the executable, and all arguments.
Some arguments may be filtered to protect sensitive information.
process.command_line.name: command_line
process.command_line.short: Full command line that started the process.

process.executable.description: Absolute path to the process executable.
process.executable.name: executable
process.executable.short: Absolute path to the process executable.

process.exit_code.description:
The exit code of the process, if this is a termination event.
The field should be absent if there is no exit code for the event (e.g. process start).
process.exit_code.name: exit_code
process.exit_code.short: The exit code of the process.

process.name.description:
Process name.
Sometimes called program name or similar.
process.name.name: name

process.parent.args.description:
Array of process arguments.
May be filtered to protect sensitive information.
process.parent.args.name: parent.args

process.parent.args_count.description:
Length of the process.args array.
This field can be useful for querying or performing bucket analysis on how many arguments were provided to start a process. More arguments may be an indication of suspicious activity.
process.parent.args_count.name: parent.args_count

process.parent.command_line.description:
Full command line that started the process, including the absolute path to the executable, and all arguments.
Some arguments may be filtered to protect sensitive information.
process.parent.command_line.name: parent.command_line
process.parent.command_line.short: Full command line that started the process.

process.parent.executable.description: Absolute path to the process executable.
process.parent.executable.name: parent.executable
process.parent.executable.short: Absolute path to the process executable.

process.parent.exit_code.description:
The exit code of the process, if this is a termination event.
The field should be absent if there is no exit code for the event (e.g. process start).
process.parent.exit_code.name: parent.exit_code
process.parent.exit_code.short: The exit code of the process.

process.parent.name.description:
Process name.
Sometimes called program name or similar.
process.parent.name.name: parent.name

process.parent.pgid.description: Identifier of the group of processes the process belongs to.
process.parent.pgid.name: parent.pgid
process.parent.pgid.short: Identifier of the group of processes the process belongs to.

process.parent.title.description:
Process title.
The proctitle, some times the same as process name. Can also be different: for example a browser setting its title to the web page currently opened.
process.parent.title.name: parent.title

process.parent.uptime.description: Seconds the process has been up.
process.parent.uptime.name: parent.uptime
process.parent.uptime.short: Seconds the process has been up.

process.parent.working_directory.description: The working directory of the process.
process.parent.working_directory.name: parent.working_directory
process.parent.working_directory.short: The working directory of the process.

process.pgid.description: Identifier of the group of processes the process belongs to.
process.pgid.name: pgid
process.pgid.short: Identifier of the group of processes the process belongs to.

process.title.description:
Process title.
The proctitle, some times the same as process name. Can also be different: for example a browser setting its title to the web page currently opened.
process.title.name: title

process.uptime.description: Seconds the process has been up.
process.uptime.name: uptime
process.uptime.short: Seconds the process has been up.

process.working_directory.description: The working directory of the process.
process.working_directory.name: working_directory
process.working_directory.short: The working directory of the process.

related.ip.description: All of the IPs seen on your event.
related.ip.name: ip
related.ip.short: All of the IPs seen on your event.

server.address.description:
Some event server addresses are defined ambiguously. The event will sometimes list an IP, a domain or a unix socket.  You should always store the raw address in the `.address` field.
Then it should be duplicated to `.ip` or `.domain`, depending on which one it is.
server.address.name: address

server.as.number.description: Unique number allocated to the autonomous system. The autonomous system number (ASN) uniquely identifies each network on the Internet.
server.as.number.name: number
server.as.number.short: Unique number allocated to the autonomous system. The autonomous system number (ASN) uniquely identifies each network on the Internet.

server.bytes.description: Bytes sent from the server to the client.
server.bytes.name: bytes
server.bytes.short: Bytes sent from the server to the client.

server.geo.name.description:
User-defined description of a location, at the level of granularity they care about.
Could be the name of their data centers, the floor number, if this describes a local physical entity, city names.
Not typically used in automated geolocation.
server.geo.name.name: name

server.ip.description:
IP address of the server.
Can be one or multiple IPv4 or IPv6 addresses.
server.ip.name: ip

server.nat.ip.description:
Translated ip of destination based NAT sessions (e.g. internet to private DMZ)
Typically used with load balancers, firewalls, or routers.
server.nat.ip.name: nat.ip

server.nat.port.description:
Translated port of destination based NAT sessions (e.g. internet to private DMZ)
Typically used with load balancers, firewalls, or routers.
server.nat.port.name: nat.port

server.packets.description: Packets sent from the server to the client.
server.packets.name: packets
server.packets.short: Packets sent from the server to the client.

server.registered_domain.description:
The highest registered server domain, stripped of the subdomain.
For example, the registered domain for "foo.google.com" is "google.com".
This value can be determined precisely with a list like the public suffix list (http://publicsuffix.org). Trying to approximate this by simply taking the last two labels will not work well for TLDs such as "co.uk".
server.registered_domain.name: registered_domain
server.registered_domain.short: The highest registered server domain, stripped of the subdomain.

server.top_level_domain.description:
The effective top level domain (eTLD), also known as the domain suffix, is the last part of the domain name. For example, the top level domain for google.com is "com".
This value can be determined precisely with a list like the public suffix list (http://publicsuffix.org). Trying to approximate this by simply taking the last label will not work well for effective TLDs such as "co.uk".
server.top_level_domain.name: top_level_domain
server.top_level_domain.short: The effective top level domain (com, org, net, co.uk).

server.user.domain.description:
Name of the directory the user is a member of.
For example, an LDAP or Active Directory domain name.
server.user.domain.name: domain
server.user.domain.short: Name of the directory the user is a member of.

server.user.group.domain.description:
Name of the directory the group is a member of.
For example, an LDAP or Active Directory domain name.
server.user.group.domain.name: domain
server.user.group.domain.short: Name of the directory the group is a member of.

server.user.group.id.description: Unique identifier for the group on the system/platform.
server.user.group.id.name: id
server.user.group.id.short: Unique identifier for the group on the system/platform.

server.user.hash.description:
Unique user hash to correlate information for a user in anonymized form.
Useful if `user.id` or `user.name` contain confidential information and cannot be used.
server.user.hash.name: hash
server.user.hash.short: Unique user hash to correlate information for a user in anonymized form.

server.user.id.description: One or multiple unique identifiers of the user.
server.user.id.name: id
server.user.id.short: One or multiple unique identifiers of the user.

server.user.name.description: Short name or login of the user.
server.user.name.name: name
server.user.name.short: Short name or login of the user.

service.ephemeral_id.description:
Ephemeral identifier of this service (if one exists).
This id normally changes across restarts, but `service.id` does not.
service.ephemeral_id.name: ephemeral_id

service.id.description:
Unique identifier of the running service. If the service is comprised of many nodes, the `service.id` should be the same for all nodes.
This id should uniquely identify the service. This makes it possible to correlate logs and metrics for one specific service, no matter which particular node emitted the event.
Note that if you need to see the events from one specific host of the service, you should filter on that `host.name` or `host.id` instead.
service.id.name: id
service.id.short: Unique identifier of the running service.

service.name.description:
Name of the service data is collected from.
The name of the service is normally user given. This allows for distributed services that run on multiple hosts to correlate the related instances based on the name.
In the case of Elasticsearch the `service.name` could contain the cluster name. For Beats the `service.name` is by default a copy of the `service.type` field if no name is specified.
service.name.name: name

service.node.name.description:
Name of a service node.
This allows for two nodes of the same service running on the same host to be differentiated. Therefore, `service.node.name` should typically be unique across nodes of a given service.
In the case of Elasticsearch, the `service.node.name` could contain the unique node name within the Elasticsearch cluster. In cases where the service doesn't have the concept of a node name, the host name or container name can be used to distinguish running instances that make up this service. If those do not provide uniqueness (e.g. multiple instances of the service running on the same host) - the node name can be manually set.
service.node.name.name: node.name

service.type.description:
The type of the service data is collected from.
The type can be used to group and correlate logs and metrics from one service type.
Example: If logs or metrics are collected from Elasticsearch, `service.type` would be `elasticsearch`.
service.type.name: type

service.version.description:
Version of the service the data was collected from.
This allows to look at a data set only for a specific version of a service.
service.version.name: version

source.address.description:
Some event source addresses are defined ambiguously. The event will sometimes list an IP, a domain or a unix socket.  You should always store the raw address in the `.address` field.
Then it should be duplicated to `.ip` or `.domain`, depending on which one it is.
source.address.name: address

source.as.number.description: Unique number allocated to the autonomous system. The autonomous system number (ASN) uniquely identifies each network on the Internet.
source.as.number.name: number
source.as.number.short: Unique number allocated to the autonomous system. The autonomous system number (ASN) uniquely identifies each network on the Internet.

source.bytes.description: Bytes sent from the source to the destination.
source.bytes.name: bytes
source.bytes.short: Bytes sent from the source to the destination.

source.geo.name.description:
User-defined description of a location, at the level of granularity they care about.
Could be the name of their data centers, the floor number, if this describes a local physical entity, city names.
Not typically used in automated geolocation.
source.geo.name.name: name

source.ip.description:
IP address of the source.
Can be one or multiple IPv4 or IPv6 addresses.
source.ip.name: ip

source.nat.ip.description:
Translated ip of source based NAT sessions (e.g. internal client to internet)
Typically connections traversing load balancers, firewalls, or routers.
source.nat.ip.name: nat.ip

source.nat.port.description:
Translated port of source based NAT sessions. (e.g. internal client to internet)
Typically used with load balancers, firewalls, or routers.
source.nat.port.name: nat.port

source.packets.description: Packets sent from the source to the destination.
source.packets.name: packets
source.packets.short: Packets sent from the source to the destination.

source.registered_domain.description:
The highest registered source domain, stripped of the subdomain.
For example, the registered domain for "foo.google.com" is "google.com".
This value can be determined precisely with a list like the public suffix list (http://publicsuffix.org). Trying to approximate this by simply taking the last two labels will not work well for TLDs such as "co.uk".
source.registered_domain.name: registered_domain
source.registered_domain.short: The highest registered source domain, stripped of the subdomain.

source.top_level_domain.description:
The effective top level domain (eTLD), also known as the domain suffix, is the last part of the domain name. For example, the top level domain for google.com is "com".
This value can be determined precisely with a list like the public suffix list (http://publicsuffix.org). Trying to approximate this by simply taking the last label will not work well for effective TLDs such as "co.uk".
source.top_level_domain.name: top_level_domain
source.top_level_domain.short: The effective top level domain (com, org, net, co.uk).

source.user.domain.description:
Name of the directory the user is a member of.
For example, an LDAP or Active Directory domain name.
source.user.domain.name: domain
source.user.domain.short: Name of the directory the user is a member of.

source.user.group.domain.description:
Name of the directory the group is a member of.
For example, an LDAP or Active Directory domain name.

tls.client.hash.sha256.short: Certificate fingerprint using the SHA256 digest of DER-encoded version of certificate offered by the client. For consistency with other hash values, this value should be formatted as an uppercase hash.

tls.client.server_name.short: Also called an SNI, this tells the server which hostname to which the client is attempting to connect. When this value is available, it should get copied to `destination.domain`.

tls.next_protocol.description: String indicating the protocol being tunneled. Per the values in the IANA registry (https://www.iana.org/assignments/tls-extensiontype-values/tls-extensiontype-values.xhtml#alpn-protocol-ids), this string should be lower case.

tls.resumed.description: Boolean flag indicating if this TLS connection was resumed from an existing TLS negotiation.
tls.resumed.name: resumed
tls.resumed.short: Boolean flag indicating if this TLS connection was resumed from an existing TLS negotiation.

trace.id.description:
Unique identifier of the trace.
A trace groups multiple events like transactions that belong together. For example, a user request handled by multiple inter-connected services.
trace.id.name: trace.id

transaction.id.description:
Unique identifier of the transaction.
A transaction is the highest level of work measured within a service, such as a request to a server.
transaction.id.name: transaction.id

url.domain.description:
Domain of the url, such as "www.elastic.co".
In some cases a URL may refer to an IP and/or port directly, without a domain name. In this case, the IP address would go to the `domain` field.
url.domain.name: domain

url.extension.description:
The field contains the file extension from the original request url.
The file extension is only set if it exists, as not every url has a file extension.
The leading period must not be included. For example, the value must be "png", not ".png".
url.extension.name: extension
url.extension.short: File extension from the original request url.

url.fragment.description:
Portion of the url after the `#`, such as "top".
The `#` is not part of the fragment.
url.fragment.name: fragment
url.fragment.short: Portion of the url after the `#`.

url.full.description: If full URLs are important to your use case, they should be stored in `url.full`, whether this field is reconstructed or present in the event source.
url.full.name: full

url.original.description:
Unmodified original url as seen in the event source.
Note that in network monitoring, the observed URL may be a full URL, whereas in access logs, the URL is often just represented as a path.
This field is meant to represent the URL as it was observed, complete or not.
url.original.name: original
url.original.short: Unmodified original url as seen in the event source.

url.path.description: Path of the request, such as "/search".
url.path.name: path
url.path.short: Path of the request, such as "/search".

url.port.description: Port of the request, such as 443.
url.port.name: port
url.port.short: Port of the request, such as 443.

url.query.description:
The query field describes the query string of the request, such as "q=elasticsearch".
The `?` is excluded from the query string. If a URL contains no `?`, there is no query field. If there is a `?` but no query, the query field exists with an empty string. The `exists` query can be used to differentiate between the two cases.
url.query.name: query

url.registered_domain.description:
The highest registered url domain, stripped of the subdomain.
For example, the registered domain for "foo.google.com" is "google.com".
This value can be determined precisely with a list like the public suffix list (http://publicsuffix.org). Trying to approximate this by simply taking the last two labels will not work well for TLDs such as "co.uk".
url.registered_domain.name: registered_domain
url.registered_domain.short: The highest registered url domain, stripped of the subdomain.

url.scheme.description:
Scheme of the request, such as "https".
Note: The `:` is not part of the scheme.
url.scheme.name: scheme

url.top_level_domain.description:
The effective top level domain (eTLD), also known as the domain suffix, is the last part of the domain name. For example, the top level domain for google.com is "com".
This value can be determined precisely with a list like the public suffix list (http://publicsuffix.org). Trying to approximate this by simply taking the last label will not work well for effective TLDs such as "co.uk".
url.top_level_domain.name: top_level_domain
url.top_level_domain.short: The effective top level domain (com, org, net, co.uk).

user.domain.name: domain
user.domain.short: Name of the directory the user is a member of.

user_agent.original.name: original

user_agent.os.family.name: family
user_agent.os.family.short: OS family (such as redhat, debian, freebsd, windows).

user_agent.os.full.description: Operating system name, including the version or code name.
user_agent.os.full.name: full
user_agent.os.full.short: Operating system name, including the version or code name.

user_agent.os.kernel.description: Operating system kernel version as a raw string.
user_agent.os.kernel.name: kernel
user_agent.os.kernel.short: Operating system kernel version as a raw string.

user_agent.os.name.description: Operating system name, without the version.
user_agent.os.name.name: name
user_agent.os.name.short: Operating system name, without the version.

user_agent.os.platform.description: Operating system platform (such centos, ubuntu, windows).
user_agent.os.platform.name: platform
user_agent.os.platform.short: Operating system platform (such centos, ubuntu, windows).

user_agent.os.version.short: Operating system version as a raw string.

vulnerability.category.description:
The type of system or architecture that the vulnerability affects. These may be platform-specific (for example, Debian or SUSE) or general (for example, Database or Firewall). For example (https://qualysguard.qualys.com/qwebhelp/fo_portal/knowledgebase/vulnerability_categories.htm)
This field must be an array.
vulnerability.category.name: category

vulnerability.classification.description: The classification of the vulnerability scoring system. For example (https://www.first.org/cvss/)
vulnerability.classification.name: classification

vulnerability.description.description: The description of the vulnerability that provides additional context of the vulnerability. For example (https://cve.mitre.org/about/faqs.html#cve_entry_descriptions_created)
vulnerability.description.example: In macOS before 2.12.6, there is a vulnerability in the RPC...
vulnerability.description.name: description

vulnerability.enumeration.description: The type of identifier used for this vulnerability. For example (https://cve.mitre.org/about/)
vulnerability.enumeration.name: enumeration

vulnerability.id.description: The identification (ID) is the number portion of a vulnerability entry. It includes a unique identification number for the vulnerability. For example (https://cve.mitre.org/about/faqs.html#what_is_cve_id)
vulnerability.id.name: id

vulnerability.reference.description: A resource that provides additional information, context, and mitigations for the identified vulnerability.
vulnerability.reference.name: reference

vulnerability.report_id.description: The report or scan identification number.
vulnerability.report_id.name: report_id

vulnerability.scanner.vendor.description: The name of the vulnerability scanner vendor.
vulnerability.scanner.vendor.name: scanner.vendor

vulnerability.score.base.description:
Scores can range from 0.0 to 10.0, with 10.0 being the most severe.
Base scores cover an assessment for exploitability metrics (attack vector, complexity, privileges, and user interaction), impact metrics (confidentialy, integrity, and availability), and scope. For example (https://www.first.org/cvss/specification-document)
vulnerability.score.base.name: score.base

vulnerability.score.environmental.description:
Scores can range from 0.0 to 10.0, with 10.0 being the most severe.
Environmental scores cover an assessment for any modified Base metrics, confidentiality, integrity, and availability requirements. For example (https://www.first.org/cvss/specification-document)
vulnerability.score.environmental.name: score.environmental

vulnerability.score.temporal.description:
Scores can range from 0.0 to 10.0, with 10.0 being the most severe.
Temporal scores cover an assessment for code maturity, remediation level, and confidence. For example (https://www.first.org/cvss/specification-document)
vulnerability.score.temporal.name: score.temporal

vulnerability.score.version.description:
The National Vulnerability Database (NVD) provides qualitative severity rankings of "Low", "Medium", and "High" for CVSS v2.0 base score ranges in addition to the severity ratings for CVSS v3.0 as they are defined in the CVSS v3.0 specification.
CVSS is owned and managed by FIRST.Org, Inc. (FIRST), a US-based non-profit organization, whose mission is to help computer security incident response teams across the world. For example (https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln-metrics/cvss)
vulnerability.score.version.name: score.version

vulnerability.severity.description: The severity of the vulnerability can help with metrics and internal prioritization regarding remediation. For example (https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln-metrics/cvss)
vulnerability.severity.name: severity
